bestBHT.bht: There will come a day when the gate will be shut, and those who have not striven to enter will be left outside. The Master of the house is depicted as calmly looking on to see who will 'strive' while entrance is practicable. However, this opportunity will have an end when the Master Himself rises and shuts the door, after which there will be no admittance. It is a warning that we must strive now while the door is open, for a time will come when it will be altogether impossible to enter.

Henry Alford: A reason why this strive is so important:—because there will be a day when the gate will be shut.
On the spiritual import, see note on Matt. xxv. 11.
'Ye are none of my family—have no relationship with me.'
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: At present he is represented as in a sitting posture, as if calmly looking on to see who will 'strive,' while entrance is practicable, and who will merely 'seek' to enter in."
But this is to have an end, by the great Master of the house Himself rising and shutting the door, after which there will be no admittance.
'Lord, Lord'—emphatic reduplication, expressive of the earnestness now felt, but too late.
Albert Barnes: The figure here used is taken from the conduct of a housekeeper, who is willing to see his friends, and who at the proper time keeps his doors open.
But there is a proper time for closing them, when he will not see his guests.
At night it would be improper and vain to seek an entrance - the house would be shut.
Marvin Vincent: When once [αφ ου] . Lit., from the time that. Compare ver. 7.
Whence [ποθεν] . Of what family. See John 7:27: 'We know whence he (Jesus) is;' i.e., we know his birthplace and family.
John Calvin: It is no slight assistance to the understanding to read, in immediate connection, those passages which are closely related in meaning.
He warns us that we must avail ourselves of the opportunity, while it is offered.
Christ therefore threatens, that the door will at length be shut, and that those who are looking for companions are in danger of being refused admission.
Philip Schaff: A time will come when it will be altogether impossible to enter."
The feast is to begin, and the expected guests, the members of the family, are all there.
Ye are strangers to me, not members of my family, not expected at my feast.
Archibald T. Robertson: It is an awkward construction, αφ' ου = απο τουτου οτε with αν and the aorist subjunctive (εγερθη and αποκλειση).
Note effective aorist tense and perfective use of απο, slammed the door fast.
First aorist middle subjunctive of αρχομα with αφ' ου αν like εγερθη and αποκλειση.
John Gill: shows how near some persons may come to heaven, and yet not enter there
he will not own them, and express any approbation of them, as his; but will treat them as strangers
they did not come from heaven, they were not heaven born souls, or partakers of the heavenly calling
John Wesley: And even agonizing will not avail, after the door is shut. Agonize, therefore, now by faith, prayer, holiness, patience.
And ye begin to stand without — Till then they had not thought of it! O how new will that sense of their misery be? How late? How lasting?
I know not whence ye are - I know not, that is, I approve not of your ways.

bhtAttempts.bht: There will come a day when the gate will be shut, and those who have not striven to enter will be left outside. It is important to understand the spiritual significance of this, as it emphasizes the need for earnest effort in seeking entrance. The Master of the house is depicted in a sitting posture, calmly observing who will strive and who will merely seek. But the time for entrance will eventually end, as the Master Himself rises and shuts the door forever. Those who then cry out, saying Lord, Lord, will be met with the heartbreaking response that they have no relationship with Him. This verse serves as a warning, urging us to take advantage of the opportunity to enter while it is still available.

There will come a day when the gate will be shut, and those who have not striven to enter will be left outside. It is important to understand the spiritual significance of this, as it emphasizes the need for earnest effort in seeking entrance. The Master of the house is depicted in a sitting posture, calmly looking on to see who will 'strive,' while entrance is practicable. But this is to have an end, by the great Master of the house Himself rising and shutting the door, after which there will be no admittance.

There will come a day when the gate will be shut, and those who have not striven to enter will be left outside. The Master of the house is depicted as calmly looking on to see who will 'strive' while entrance is still possible. However, this opportunity will have an end when the Master Himself rises and slams the door shut, allowing no admittance. Those who seek entrance too late will be met with the heartbreaking reality that they have no relationship with the Master. It is therefore crucial to strive for entry while there is still time.

There will come a day when the gate will be shut, and those who have not striven to enter will be left outside. The Master of the house Himself will rise and slam the door shut, after which there will be no admittance. It is a solemn warning, urging us to take advantage of the opportunity to enter while it is still available. The need for earnest effort in seeking entrance is emphasized, as those who merely seek without striving will be strangers to the Master and denied entrance.

There will come a day when the gate will be shut, and those who have not striven to enter will be left outside. The Master of the house is depicted as calmly looking on to see who will 'strive' while entrance is practicable. However, this opportunity will have an end when the Master Himself rises and shuts the door, after which there will be no admittance. It is a warning that we must strive now while the door is open, for a time will come when it will be altogether impossible to enter.
